mapped_songs.post_title: Songs that help me with my anxiety üíîüíò
mapped_songs.comment_text:
When I was 16, after 10 years of compulsory public education, I watched a couple of friends leave to further their tertiary educations overseas, while I could only get a local polytechnic diploma. 2-3 years after that, I watch more friends walk proudly into various local universities, while my educational journey came to an end. I came from a poor family and my father could only send me for basic education and nothing more as I had 3 younger siblings who were still schooling. After 3 years in the military, I began working and became the family bread winner. I never stopped working for almost 25 years and slowly climbed up the career ladder. A few years ago, I hear this song and it struck a cord in me. I decided it was time. I enrolled in graduate school at 45. Next to the lecturer, I was the oldest person in class. Everywhere I went on campus, I stood out like a sore thumb. Everyone was on laptops and tablets, while I was on books, papers and pencils. But I didn't give up, I kept turning to this song to keep me going. THIS was MY fight song. I struggled hard but help soon came. Classmates half my age who once spurred the 'old dude' from groups in class, turned to me for life advice and in turn, helped me navigate the digital world and gadgets and online submissions. I still turned to this song to keep the fire going when I wanted to give up.

I graduated last year, ahead of schedule, 4 years out of a 5 year part time degree programme. My parents couldn't make it as they were too frail. There was no one in the audience clapping for a 49 year old graduate. But I was proud. I had made it. And this song was one of those songs that just kept me telling myself ... I can do this!
mapped_songs.ananki_reasoning: The human describes experiencing educational and socioeconomic disadvantages compared to their peers - watching friends pursue higher education while they could only obtain a polytechnic diploma due to their family's financial constraints. 'Fight Song' by Rachel Platten is an empowerment anthem about persevering through adversity and finding inner strength despite obstacles. The song's core message ('this is my fight song, prove I'm alright song') directly addresses overcoming feelings of inadequacy and building self-belief - which aligns perfectly with needing confidence when facing systematic disadvantages. While the context describes anxiety and sadness, the song itself serves as a confidence-building, empowerment tool to combat those feelings rather than wallow in them.
